name: hydropower plant construction, run-of-river | hydropower plant, run-of-river | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/1410/documentation

This dataset represents a run-of-river power plant unit for European countries except from Switzerland. Due to the fact that this dataset is based on data of Swiss and Austrian dams and then extrapolated to the rest of Europe, the uncertainty is increased. A representative sample of various types of power plants in Switzerland and Austria is taken into account. The calculations are based on the information and data of the following run-of-river power plants: Rupperswil-Auenstein (Baumann 1949), Wildegg-Brugg (NOK 1956), Birsfelden (Aegerter et al. 1954), Donaukraftwerk Greifenstein (Brux 1983; max. Leistung 237 MW) and Rheinkraftwerk Albbruck-Dogern (Radag 1979) as well as the new construction of the power plant Ruppoldingen. The determined specific data was then related to the entire power plant park of Switzerland with an annual net electricity output of 15484 GWh/a (BEW 2001a). Lifetime is assumed to be 80 years for the structural part (including cement, reinforcing steel, diesel, electricity, transportation and explosives) and 40 years for the rest of materials. The data refers to plant construction of a mix of types of dams built between 1945 and the beginning of the 1980s; therefore they might not be representative for more modern construction, for an individual type and for small-scale and smallest-scale plants. ;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of the various construction materials (cement, reinforcing steel, chromium steel, low-alloyed steel, explosives, gravel) for the construction of a run-of-river hydro power plant.

This activity ends with a run-of-river hydro power plant, with a lifetime of 80 years (structural part) resp. 40 years (all remaining parts). The dataset includes particle emissions during the construction activities. Transformers are included, while further infrastructure like outdoor substations, high-voltage lines, etc. are excluded. The dataset doesn't include the flue ash input, although flue ash is used as concrete additive. Due to the lack of information or insignificant amounts, copper consumption in generators, the need for landfill capacity for the excavated materials of adits and the recycling potential of materials after expiration of the life time are not taken into account.
category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The dataset represents the average of a characteristic sample of run-of-river hydropower plants valid for European conditions (i.e. all European countries modelled in ecoinvent with hydropower except from Switzerland).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: ;Run-of-river power plants are hydro power plants without important reservoirs. Depending on the net head of the power plant, high-pressure, medium-pressure and low-pressure systems can be distinguished. Low-pressure power plants including river power stations and canal power plants are very common; therefore these two types of run-of-river power stations are covered in the dataset. To some extent, high-pressure as well as medium-pressure run-of-river systems can be considered as reservoir power stations, e.g. as unit in plant groups that are dominated by storage power plants, but also include alpine run power stations.;;The technology used in the dataset has an overall efficiency of 82%, more modern technologies show an overall efficiency of about 88%. The overall efficiency (current: 0,82; modern: 0,88) is composed of the efficiency of the works water channel (current: 1,00; modern: 1,00), the turbine (current: 0,87; modern: 0,91), the generator (current: 0,96; modern: 0,98) and the transformer (current: 0,98; modern: 0,99). For the calculation of the works water channel of run-of-river plants an efficiency of 100% is assumed.;;The efficiency losses in turbines depend on the turbine type (Kaplan, Francis, Pelton, etc.), the turbine output and on the ratio between turbined water amount and the rated water amount. In König, examples for curve progressions of the relationship between these variables are shown. For current power plants an efficiency of 87% is assumed, more modern turbines show an efficiency of about 91%.;;The efficiency of generators depends on the output, the rotation speed of the generator and the cooling system. For today’s power plants an efficiency of approximately 96% is assumed, modern generators show an efficiency of about 98%. The efficiency of transformers amounts to 98%, respectively 99%.;;References:;König F., von (1985) Bau von Wasserkraftanlagen. C.F. Müller, Karlsruhe.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The dataset is based on data of various types of dams in Switzerland and Austria and extrapolated to European countries (except from Switzerland). Therefore uncertainty is increased.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Sampling procedure based on literature. Some information regarding the results is given without source notes or detailed, comprehensible derivation due to the guaranteed confidential treatment of data.

flow.name: hydropower plant, run-of-river
flow.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Data are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Due to the fact that there already are large uncertainties regarding data for Swiss and Austrian power plants, the uncertainty factors were not adopted to European conditions. Where possible more suitable modules were used.

In general it is assumed that emissions during the construction of run-of-river plants are lower than emissions during the construction of reservoir power plants. This can be explained by the fact that large parts of the excavation material accrue from digging a canal and to some extend this dredging work is done underwater where no particles are emitted. In addition, dams in Switzerland are usually of larger dimension than run-of-river plants.

The sample of run-of-river plants regarding the excavation material show values of 3.5-22.8 kg/(kWh/a) with an average value of 15.2 kg/(kWh/a). The average value is used for further calculations. In order to calculate the particle emissions per kg excavation material, the emission data of mining limestone and bauxite is used. Information about assumed percentages is derived from detailed data of the construction of the power plant in Wildegg-Brugg. For the construction of this plant 3.1 Mio. m3 gravel and mud and  0.3 Mio. m3 rock was moved. This equals to 91% of gravel and 9% of rock. For the latter particle emissions of mining bauxite (1.5 g(TSP)/kg excavation material) are assumed. Regarding the excavation of gravel and mud, it has to be considered that the excavation to some extend is done underwater. Based on this information in an underwater ratio of 2/3 is assumed. To calculate the amount of gravel the particle emissions of mining limestone (0.16 g(TSP)/kg excavation material) are multiplied by a factor of 1/3. This results in total emissions of about 0.19 g(TSP)/kg excavation material for run-of-river plants. For the size distribution the values of reservoir power plants are assumed. Hence emissions caused during the excavation process for particles >10um of 1.95 [g/(kWh/a)] and for total suspended dust (TSP) of 2.8 [g/(kWh/a)] can be calculated.

For the process of concrete mixing the values of reservoir power plants are used (i.e. 0.06 kg(TSP)/t concrete. With an average concrete consumption of 0.00052 m3/(kWh/a) and a concrete density of 2200 kg/m3, emissions for total suspended dust (TSP) of 0.068 [g/(kWh/a)] and for particles >10um of 0.034 [g/(kWh/a)] can be calculated.

	                 Emissions [g/(kWh/a)   Emissions [kg/unit]
total dust TSP	        2.85	                        4.43.10^7	
Particles >10 mm	        2.0	                        3.08.10^7

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

Estimation. Data are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Due to the fact that there already are large uncertainties regarding data for Swiss and Austrian power plants, the uncertainty factors were not adopted to European conditions. Where possible more suitable modules were used.

In general it is assumed that emissions during the construction of run-of-river plants are lower than emissions during the construction of reservoir power plants. This can be explained by the fact that large parts of the excavation material accrue from digging a canal and to some extend this dredging work is done underwater where no particles are emitted. In addition, dams in Switzerland are usually of larger dimension than run-of-river plants.

The sample of run-of-river plants regarding the excavation material show values of 3.5-22.8 kg/(kWh/a) with an average value of 15.2 kg/(kWh/a). The average value is used for further calculations. In order to calculate the particle emissions per kg excavation material, the emission data of mining limestone and bauxite is used. Information about assumed percentages is derived from detailed data of the construction of the power plant in Wildegg-Brugg. For the construction of this plant 3.1 Mio. m3 gravel and mud and  0.3 Mio. m3 rock was moved. This equals to 91% of gravel and 9% of rock. For the latter particle emissions of mining bauxite (1.5 g(TSP)/kg excavation material) are assumed. Regarding the excavation of gravel and mud, it has to be considered that the excavation to some extend is done underwater. Based on this information an underwater ratio of 2/3 is assumed. To calculate the amount of gravel the particle emissions of mining limestone (0.16 g(TSP)/kg excavation material) are multiplied by a factor of 1/3. This results in total emissions of about 0.19 g(TSP)/kg excavation material for run-of-river plants. For the size distribution the values of reservoir power plants are assumed. Hence emissions caused during the excavation process for particles <2.5um of 0.14 [g/(kWh/a)] and for total suspended dust (TSP) of 2.8 [g/(kWh/a)] can be calculated.

For the process of concrete mixing the values of reservoir power plants are used (i.e. 0.06 kg(TSP)/t concrete. With an average concrete consumption of 0.00052 m3/(kWh/a) and a concrete density of 2200 kg/m3, emissions for total suspended dust (TSP) of 0.068 [g/(kWh/a)] and for particles <2.5um of 0.010 [g/(kWh/a)] can be calculated.

The total particle emissions caused by the construction of a run-of-river plant (mining and concrete mixing) per kWh and per power plant unit are listed below:

	                 Emissions [g/(kWh/a)   Emissions [kg/unit]
total dust TSP	        2.85	                        4.43.10^7	
Particles <2.5 mm	        0.15	                        2.32.10^6

Due to the fact that there already are large uncertainties regarding data for Swiss and Austrian power plants, the uncertainty factors were not adopted to European conditions. Where possible more suitable modules were used.

In general it is assumed that emissions during the construction of run-of-river plants are lower than emissions during the construction of reservoir power plants. This can be explained by the fact that large parts of the excavation material accrue from digging a canal and to some extend this dredging work is done underwater where no particles are emitted. In addition, dams in Switzerland are usually of larger dimension than run-of-river plants.

The sample of run-of-river plants regarding the excavation material show values of 3.5-22.8 kg/(kWh/a) with an average value of 15.2 kg/(kWh/a). The average value is used for further calculations. In order to calculate the particle emissions per kg excavation material, the emission data of mining limestone and bauxite is used. Information about assumed percentages is derived from detailed data of the construction of the power plant in Wildegg-Brugg. For the construction of this plant 3.1 Mio. m3 gravel and mud and  0.3 Mio. m3 rock was moved. This equals to 91% of gravel and 9% of rock. For the latter particle emissions of mining bauxite (1.5 g(TSP)/kg excavation material) are assumed. Regarding the excavation of gravel and mud, it has to be considered that the excavation to some extend is done underwater. Based on this information in an underwater ratio of 2/3 is assumed. To calculate the amount of gravel the particle emissions of mining limestone (0.16 g(TSP)/kg excavation material) are multiplied by a factor of 1/3. This results in total emissions of about 0.19 g(TSP)/kg excavation material for run-of-river plants. For the size distribution the values of reservoir power plants are assumed. Hence emissions caused during the excavation process for particles >2.5um and <10um of 0.7 [g/(kWh/a)] and for total suspended dust (TSP) of 2.8 [g/(kWh/a)] can be calculated.

For the process of concrete mixing the values of reservoir power plants are used (i.e. 0.06 kg(TSP)/t concrete. exchanges.description:
Estimation. Data regarding material consumption for infrastructure are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Uncertainty is increased by a factor of 0.2 because no major changes are expected and to account for the transfer of data to different geographical conditions. 

Steel in run-of-river plants is amongst others used for: reinforcement, sheet pile walls remaining in the construction, flood-gates, dam beams, cranes for stowing, trashracks, inlet rakes for turbines, rake cleaning machines, gantry cranes, turbines, generators, transformers etc. To some extent cast iron is included. The specific steel consumption of about 30 g/(kWh/yr) is estimated, compared to the specific steel consumption of reservoir power stations of about 40 g/(kWh/yr). Reinforcing steel accounts for 41% or 12.3 g/(kWh/yr). Specific reinforcing steel consumption averaged over the life time of 80 years amounts to 0.15 g/kWh or 1.90. 10^8  kg/unit.


Further references:

Baumann J. (1949) Kraftwerk Rupperswil-Auenstein. Verlag Kraftwerk Rupperswil-Auenstein AG, Rupperswil.

Brux G. (1983) Das Donaukraftwerk Greifenstein. In: Wasser, Energie, Luft,  75 (1-2), 11-13.

Erbiste P.C. (1984) Estimating gate weights. In: Water Power & Dam Construction, 36 (5), 18-23.

Herbeck H., Reismann W. (1977) Die Bauausführung grosser Talsperren und Staustufen. In: Österreichische Wasserwirtschaft, 29 (9-10), 243-264.

Nordostschweizerische Kraftwerke AG (NOK) (1956) Das Kraftwerk Wildegg-Brugg. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 74 (4), 47-52; 74 (5), 63-67; 74 (6), 83-88; 74 (7), 93-99; 74 (8), 111-116;  74 (10), 145-147; 74 (12), 167-172.

Radag A. (1979) 50 Jahre Rheinkraftwerk Albbruck-Dogern Aktiengesellschaft. Waldshut/Rhein, 1929-1979.

Stambach E. (1944) Über die Entwicklung der schweizerischen Niederdruck-Wasserkraftanlagen in den letzten 50 Jahren. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 124 (25), 321-325; 124 (26), 336-340.

Wunderle E. (1984) Der elektro-maschinelle Bereich in 30 Jahren Donauausbau - bewährte Strukturen und neue Techniken. In: Österreichische Zeitschrift für Elektrizitätswirtschaft, 37 (5-6), 142-150.

and unpublished sources

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Data regarding material consumption for infrastructure are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Uncertainty is increased by a factor of 0.2 because no major changes are expected and to account for the transfer of data to different geographical conditions. 

The life time is considered in the dataset. Compared to reservoir power stations explosive consumption is considerably lower, because there is no need for constructing long tunnel system. Explosives were used for removing firm layers of rock, for blasting cofferdams or for mining rocks. At the construction of new power plants, explosives are no longer used. Specific explosive consumption at the power plant Wildegg-Brugg amounts to 0.05g/(kWh/yr) respectively. 0.00018 kg/kg stone; averaged over the life time of 80 years amounts to 0.00063 g/kWh or 7.79 . 10^5kg/unit.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=CH
Estimation. According to experts the construction is left in situ i.e. the construction is not transported to the landfill. Generally, these constructions are not disused but after life time has expired, a new run-of-river plant is built on the same site. However, as part of the construction of the new power plant, the old construction will be demolished and transported to the landfill. In order to keep consistency, the demolition of the construction is attributed to the old power plant. For the disposal of reinforced concrete a value of 2.34 10^10 is assumed.

The consumption of gravel for run-of-river plants is based on the same assumptions as the gravel consumption for reservoir power plants. The gravel consumption is 15.98 g/kWh oder 1.97 . 10^10 kg/unit gravel.


Further references:

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Calculated value. Electricity for construction work is adapted according to the country-specific UCTE supply modules. Data are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Due to the fact that there already are large uncertainties regarding data for Swiss and Austrian power plants, the uncertainty factors were not adopted to European conditions.

During the construction phase, energy is needed for operating the machines. For the transportation railways were used to some extent. Until about 1950, steam locomotives were often used. Specific electricity consumption varies between 0.03 and 0.06 kWh/(kWh/a), with a mean value of 0.04 kWh/(kWh/a). Averaged over the life time of 80 years it amounts to 0.0005 kWh/kWh or 6.18 . 10^8 kWh/unit. The values are depending on whether wet or dry construction and what kind of sealing system was used for the construction pit. 


Further references:

Wunderle E. (1984) Der elektro-maschinelle Bereich in 30 Jahren Donauausbau - bewährte Strukturen und neue Techniken. In: Österreichische Zeitschrift für Elektrizitätswirtschaft, 37 (5-6), 142-150.
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

Steel in run-of-river plants is amongst others used for: reinforcement, sheet pile walls remaining in the construction, flood-gates, dam beams, cranes for stowing, trashracks, inlet rakes for turbines, rake cleaning machines, gantry cranes, turbines, generators, transformers etc. To some extent cast iron is included. exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Data are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Due to the fact that there already are large uncertainties regarding data for Swiss and Austrian power plants, the uncertainty factors were not adopted to European conditions. Where possible more suitable modules were used.

During the construction phase, energy is needed for operating the machines. For the transportation railways were used to some extent. Until about 1950, steam locomotives were often used. Specific fuel consumption (primarily diesel oil) amounts to around 9 g/(kWh/a), averaged over the life time of 80 years this amounts to 0.11 g/kWh. With a net calorific value of 42.8 MJ/kg it equates to an energy consumption of 5.82 . 10^9 MJ/unit. (Baumann 1949) and (NOK 1956) offer information on the topic of fuel consumption. 

Further references:

Nordostschweizerische Kraftwerke AG (NOK) (1956) Das Kraftwerk Wildegg-Brugg. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 74 (4), 47-52; 74 (5), 63-67; 74 (6), 83-88; 74 (7), 93-99; 74 (8), 111-116;  74 (10), 145-147; 74 (12), 167-172.
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Data regarding material consumption for infrastructure are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Uncertainty is increased by a factor of 0.2 because no major changes are expected and to account for the transfer of data to different geographical conditions. 

Specific cement consumption varies between 0.1-0.2 kg/(kWh/a) with a mean value of 0.15 kg/(kWh/a). With an average life time of 80 years a specific cement consumption of 1.88 g/kWh or 2.32 . 10^9 kg/unit is estimated. As expected, the values are lower and vary less than the figures calculated from the storage power plants. Not included are new bildings like the power plant in Ruppoldingen which, however has the same order of magnitude as older power plants. A comparison between two older power plants (Birsfelden and Wildegg-Brugg: Aergerter et al. 1954, NOK 1956) and a new one (Ruppoldingen) is listed in the table below:

		       Birsfelden      Wildegg-Brugg    Ruppoldingen	
Output [MW]	             85	    40                       23
Production 
potential [GWh/a]	            534	   300	              114
Cement max [kg/m3]           350	   350	              275
Cement min [kg/m3]	            250	   225	              250
Cement average [kg/m3]     300	   270	                 -
Cement total [t]	         85500             41573	           17020
Cement specific
[kg/(kWh/a)]	             0.16	   0.14	               0.15	

Furthermore, a comparison of high-pressure and medium-pressure river power plants is interesting. A broad range of power plant units with partly low storage capacity was analyzed. Hence it is possible to extrapolate the storage capacity to zero in order to get a standard value for run-of-river power stations of about 0.18 kg/(kWh/a). The small difference between the figures in the table above is due to two opposing effects. On the one hand high-pressure and medium-pressure systems have higher material requirements per volume unit turbined water than low-pressure river power stations, because pressure tunnels, pressure shafts etc. have to be constructed. On the other hand there is a considerably higher amount of energy generated per volume unit turbined water due to the higher level of the net head. Apparently, both effects compensate for each other, so that in average there is no big difference between the two power plant categories regarding the cement consumption per unit of energy produced.


Further references:

Nordostschweizerische Kraftwerke AG (NOK) (1956) Das Kraftwerk Wildegg-Brugg. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 74 (4), 47-52; 74 (5), 63-67; 74 (6), 83-88; 74 (7), 93-99; 74 (8), 111-116;  74 (10), 145-147; 74 (12), 167-172.
EcoSpold01Location=CH

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation. Data regarding material consumption for infrastructure are adopted from the Swiss and Austrian power plant sample as it stands. Uncertainty is increased by a factor of 0.2 because no major changes are expected and to account for the transfer of data to different geographical conditions. 

Steel in run-of-river plants is amongst others used for: reinforcement, sheet pile walls remaining in the construction, flood-gates, dam beams, cranes for stowing, trashracks, inlet rakes for turbines, rake cleaning machines, gantry cranes, turbines, generators, transformers etc. To some extent cast iron is included. The specific steel consumption of about 30 g/(kWh/yr) is estimated, compared to the specific steel consumption of reservoir power stations of about 40 g/(kWh/yr). Low-alloyed steel accounts for 55% or 16.5 g/(kWh/yr). Specific low-alloyed steel consumption averaged over the life time of 40 years amounts to 0.41 g/kWh or 5.11. 10^8  kg/unit.


Further references:

Herbeck H., Reismann W. (1977) Die Bauausführung grosser Talsperren und Staustufen. In: Österreichische Wasserwirtschaft, 29 (9-10), 243-264.

Nordostschweizerische Kraftwerke AG (NOK) (1956) Das Kraftwerk Wildegg-Brugg. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 74 (4), 47-52; 74 (5), 63-67; 74 (6), 83-88; 74 (7), 93-99; 74 (8), 111-116;  74 (10), 145-147; 74 (12), 167-172.

Stambach E. (1944) Über die Entwicklung der schweizerischen Niederdruck-Wasserkraftanlagen in den letzten 50 Jahren. In: Schweizerische Bauzeitung, 124 (25), 321-325; 124 (26), 336-340.
